rounds.response:
Looking at my J♠9♣ in the small-blind facing a 20 big-blind raise:

- My starting hand is marginally below average (J-high, off-suit, moderate kicker).  
- The raise is coming from the big blind (acting as the pre-flop aggressor) after I merely limped in for the 10-chip small blind; this line often indicates a real hand rather than a total steal.  
- Out of position and only 40 chips in the middle, defending here risks losing another ~20-40 chips on most flops; folding costs me just the 10 already in.

Decision: fold and preserve chips.

[Fold]

rounds.response:
I’m in the small-blind for the first time this session (Hand 8/10).  
Pot is 30, current bet to me is 20.  
My hole cards 4♣ K♠ – offsuit, low potential heads-up.

Odds are bad (roughly 4-to-1 on the call) and they rarely fold to my limp.  
Best play is preserve chips and wait for a stronger spot.

[Fold]

rounds.response:
With only 30 in the pot and 10 BB to play, this is our last opportunity to take a stand. 9♣K♦ is a clear raise in a heads-up spot – the K is robust against any one-card hand P1 might have, and the connected 9 adds some extra straight outs. Going for a standard 2.5-ish-times-the-bet-size to maximize fold-equity while still leaving room for continued play if called.

[Raise 50]
